info.name: Verisafe
info.description:
# Verisafe API Collection

**Verisafe** is the authentication and authorization service for the Academia platform. It is responsible for:

- Managing user accounts and sessions for the Academia Platform
    
- Enforcing role-based access control (RBAC)
    
- Issuing and verifying JWTs for secure communication
    
- Assigning roles and permissions to users
    
- Providing endpoints for managing accounts, roles, and permissions
    

This Postman collection provides a complete set of requests to interact with Verisafe's public and admin APIs. Use it to:

- Create and authenticate users
    
- Assign roles and permissions
    
- Inspect access control rules
    
- Test protected endpoints with JWTs
    

> ğŸ” Verisafe is built using Go and PostgreSQL, leveraging `sqlc` for type-safe database access. 
  

---

Make sure to set your `Authorization` header with a valid bearer token where required. You can use the pre-request scripts or environment variables provided in this collection.

item.name: Auth
item.description:
# ğŸ” Verisafe Auth Module

Verisafe handles **OAuth-based authentication** for the Academia ecosystem. It supports multiple third-party providers and does **not** use traditional email/password login.

## âœ… Supported OAuth Providers

- Google
    
- Microsoft
    
- Apple
    
- Spotify
    
- Discord
    

Users authenticate using their provider of choice. Upon successful login, Verisafe issues a **JWT token** used for authenticating with protected services.

---

## ğŸš€ Authentication Flow

1. **Frontend** initiates OAuth login via the desired provider.
    
2. After successful OAuth login, the frontend obtains an **OAuth access token** from the provider.
    
3. This token is sent to Verisafe for verification and user provisioning (if new).
    
4. Verisafe returns a signed **JWT access token** and **refresh token**.
    

---

## ğŸ”„ Exchange OAuth Token for Verisafe Token

**Endpoint:** `POST /auth/exchange`

**Description:** Verifies a provider-issued access token and issues Verisafe tokens

> **Warning** The authentication endpoints might not work with postman. Please try them on the browser to prevent issues

item.name: Roles & Permissions
Roles
item.description:
# ğŸ§± Roles in Verisafe

In Verisafe, a **Role** is a named collection of permissions that define what actions a user can perform within the Academia ecosystem.

Roles simplify access management by grouping relevant permissions under a single name. Instead of assigning individual permissions to users, you assign them one or more roles.

---

## ğŸ§© Role Structure

Each role contains:

- **`id`** â€“ Unique identifier
    
- **`name`** â€“ Human-readable name (e.g. `admin`, `student`, `moderator`, `system`)
    
- **`description`** â€“ Optional summary of the role's purpose
    
- **`created_at`****,** **`updated_at`** â€“ Audit timestamps
    

---

## ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ¤â€ğŸ§‘ Assigning Roles to Users

Users can have multiple roles. Each role grants its full set of permissions.

> A user's final access is the union of all permissions granted by their roles. 
  

### Example:

If a user has both `student` and `club_admin` roles, they inherit all permissions from both roles.

---

## ğŸš¨ Special Role: `system`

Verisafe includes a default role called `system`:

- It is intended for internal services and superusers
    
- It is automatically granted **all permissions**
    
- Use it with caution â€” ideal for automated jobs or admin consoles
    

---

---

## ğŸ›¡ï¸ Common Roles

| Role Name | Description |
| --- | --- |
| `student` | Basic user of the platform |
| `admin` | Full control of system resources |
| `moderator` | Limited admin powers (e.g. content review) |
| `org_owner` | Manages an organization and its users |
| `system` | Reserved for internal platform use |

---

To view or assign permissions to a role, see the **Permissions** section.

item.name: Permissions
item.description:
# ğŸ›¡ï¸ Permissions in Verisafe

Permissions in Verisafe define **what actions a user can perform** in the system. They are the core units of access control, and are always assigned **via roles** â€” users do not receive permissions directly.

---

## ğŸ¯ Permission Format

Each permission is a string following the format:  
  

```
action:entity:scope

 ```

### ğŸ” Breakdown:

- **action**: What the user can do (`create`, `read`, `update`, `delete`, etc.)
    
- **entity**: What the action applies to (`task`, `course`, `account`, etc.)
    
- **scope**: Who or what the permission applies to (`own`, `any`, or custom values)
    

### âœ… Examples:

| Permission | Meaning |
| --- | --- |
| `read:task:own` | Can read their own tasks |
| `delete:course:any` | Can delete any course |
| `update:account:own` | Can update their own account details |
| `manage:organization:own` | Can manage the organization they belong to |

---

## ğŸ“Œ Defining Permissions

Permissions are stored centrally in a `permissions` table and associated with roles via a join table (`role_permissions`). This makes it easy to:

- Reuse permissions across roles
    
- Add/remove permissions without modifying role logic
    
- Enforce access checks consistently across services
    

---

## âš™ï¸ Assigning Permissions

Permissions are **not assigned directly to users**. Instead:

1. Permissions are linked to **Roles**
    
2. Roles are assigned to **Users**
    

This makes permission management scalable and easier to reason about.

---

## ğŸš¨ Important Notes

- The `system` role automatically receives **all permissions**.
    
- Permissions should be **as granular as needed** for fine control.
    
- Always use consistent naming to avoid confusion.
    

---

## ğŸ”„ Common Permissions Examples

| Permission | Use Case |
| --- | --- |
| `create:post:own` | A user creating their own post |
| `approve:comment:any` | A moderator approving any comment |
| `view:grades:own` | A student viewing their own grades |
| `export:report:any` | An admin exporting platform-wide data |

---

> ğŸ” Verisafe's authorization layer uses these permissions to enforce Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) across Academia and its microservices.

# ğŸ›¡ï¸ Roles & Permissions

Verisafe uses **Role-Based Access Control (RBAC)** to manage what users can and cannot do across the Academia platform and its microservices.

---

## ğŸ§± Roles

A **role** is a named group of permissions.

- Users can have one or more roles.
    
- Roles are assigned at the account level.
    
- Each role represents a level of access or responsibility (e.g. `admin`, `student`, `moderator`, `system`).
    

---

## ğŸ§¾ Permissions

Each permission follows the format:

```
action:entity:scope

 ```

### âœ… Components:

- **`action`** â€” What is being done (`create`, `read`, `update`, `delete`, etc.)
    
- **`entity`** â€” The resource or object (`task`, `account`, `course`, `message`, etc.)
    
- **`scope`** â€” Context or boundary of access (`own`, `any`, `global`, `organization`, etc.)
    

### ğŸ” Examples:

| Permission | Meaning |
| --- | --- |
| `read:task:own` | Can read their own tasks |
| `update:account:own` | Can update their own account profile |
| `delete:course:any` | Can delete any course (admin-level) |
| `create:message:global` | Can create messages platform-wide |

---

## ğŸ› ï¸ Assigning Roles & Permissions

- Roles are created with a name and description.
    
- Permissions are then linked to roles.
    
- When a user is assigned a role, they inherit all its permissions.
    

### Example Flow:

1. Create role `student`
    
2. Add permissions:
    
    - `read:task:own`
        
    - `update:account:own`
        
3. Assign role `student` to user `john.doe@campus.edu`
    

---

## ğŸ” System Role

Verisafe has a special role called `system` that contains **all permissions**. It is reserved for internal services and trusted automation agents.

Use this role cautiously.

---

## ğŸ“Œ Enforcement

Authorization is enforced by:

- Checking if a user's roles contain the required permission
    
- Matching the requested action with `action:entity:scope`
    

Services using Verisafe should enforce permissions via middleware or guards at the application level.

---

For more on how to check and evaluate permissions, see the Authorization endpoints section.
